awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Molecular and Structural Mechanism of histone binding by the epigenetic regulator UHRF2
awd_abstract_narration:
Epigenetics is a layer of information that exists on top of the regular genome to regulate the expression of genes; the molecules that orchestrate this information can contribute to human health and disease. Two epigenetic molecules, called UHRF1 and UHRF2, have distinct cellular functions, but are not well characterized at the molecular level. The proposed research seeks to determine the molecular differences by which UHRF1 and UHRF2 interact with epigenetic material. The project will establish a productive and collaborative research program that provides valuable scientific training for ~12-14 undergraduate students at Eastern Michigan University (EMU). Strong mentorship and cross-disciplinary training will provide students with critical thinking and research skills so they are prepared to succeed in future biomedical careers. The research plan will also be integrated into undergraduate biochemistry lab courses to give additional students the learning benefits of research. Together, the proposed work will strengthen the academic and research environment at EMU and increase basic knowledge in the area of epigenetics. 

Histone reader proteins engage epigenetic modifications and play a central role in the regulation of many nuclear processes such as transcription, DNA replication and DNA repair. The detailed molecular mechanisms by which many of these proteins mediate histone recognition remain unknown; thus this represents a major gap in our current understanding of how these proteins impart specificity and regulate the epigenetic apparatus. This research focuses on the histone reader protein UHRF2, a close homolog of UHRF1 with distinct nuclear functions. While UHRF1-histone interactions are well studied, very little is known on the molecular and structural requirements of histone recognition by UHRF2. The goal of this project is to determine the molecular and structural mechanisms by which the histone binding domains of UHRF2 functionally interact with histone H3. Equilibrium binding assays, mutagenesis and crystallographic approaches will be utilized to elucidate the mechanisms that dictate histone-binding specificity between UHRF1 and UHRF2. This research will provide molecular insights as to how histone reader proteins distinguish and engage their cognate PTMs and advance fundamental understanding of epigenetic regulation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Deepening the understanding of the histone binding properties of UHRF2

UHRF1 and UHRF2 are epigenetic regulators with roles in DNA methylation, histone modification and gene regulation.  While the histone binding properties of the TTD and PHD of UHRF1 is well characterized, the mechanism by which the same domains of UHRF2 engage the H3 tail is poorly understood. A biochemical and molecular dissection of the TTD-PHD, TTD, and PHD of UHRF2 was performed and compared to the histone binding activities UHRF1. It was found that unlike UHRF1, whose PHD is the main contributor to histone binding versus the TTD, the TTD of UHRF2 demonstrates high affinity interactions while the PHD weakly binds to the H3 tail. In addition, the TTD and PHD domains of UHRF2 cooperate to interact with H3 and this relies on set of specific amino acids. Systematic mutational analysis revealed that like UHRF1, a conserved set of aromatic amino acids in the TTD is critical for binding trimethylated lysine 9 of H3 and a conserved aspartic acid in the PHD is essential for binding arginine 2 of H3. However, a unique asparagine in the same H3 binding pocket within the PHD of UHRF2 was shown to responsible for weakening the binding affinity by reducing a potential electrostatic interaction. Lastly a unique stretch of ~30 amino acids in the TTD of UHRF2 was determined to lack histone binding activities and biophysical analysis demonstrated it to be a disordered region. These differences and similarities identified between UHRF1 and UHRF2 is a useful foundation for potentially creating novel molecules that can selectively target these proteins.

 

Broader Impacts: Training of students and incorporation of a research experience in the classroom

EMU is a public institution that primarily serves the greater Detroit population and is regularly recognized as one of the most diverse universities in the Midwest. As of 2022, over 50% of the student body are of non-white ethnicity and many are Pell Grant Recipients and/or first-generation college students. This project has provided hands on training for 32 students, mostly undergraduates and from underrepresented groups, in scientific research through one-on-one mentorship. In additional to obtaining relevant laboratory skills via an individualized hypothesis-driven project, each student also was given the opportunity to further develop as a scientist by attending group meetings and presenting at local and national conferences. Most students that have graduated from my laboratory have gone on to pursue STEM/Medical careers including PhD/MS programs, Medical school, Dental School, Pharmacy School, and Research Technician.

 

In addition, the Biochemistry Lab class (CHEM 453W) at EMU was transformed into a CURE (Classroom Undergraduate Research Experience)-grant proposal writing course. This involved the students testing out a grant-related research hypotheses by performing a set of connected experiments. Students also had a semester long intensive project of writing an NSF-style grant in which students developed a novel research proposal based on a research problem or question on a specific protein of their choosing. Together, this process teaches the student to learn and think on a more sophisticated level that extends beyond the college classroom and challenged them to critically think deeply about their misconception about how the scientific process works. A total of 36 students took CHEM453W under my instruction, most of which had never had the opportunity to perform research prior to taking the class. Thus, an authentic, meaningful research experience was made possible for these students through the Biochemistry Lab class.
